In this study, the direct synthesis conditions of dimethyl carbonate (DMC) from methanol and CO2 were controlled under the dual supercritical conditions, whose temperature was higher than the maximal critical temperature of CO2 and methanol (>239 ℃), and the partial pressure for each reactant was larger than its partial critical pressure (PCO2 > 7.4 MPa and Pmethanol > 8.1 MPa). A series of CeO2 catalysts with different morphologies including traditional nanorod, amorphous and flower structures were synthesized by hydrothermal method. The prepared catalysts were characterized by the BET, XRD, SEM, NH3/CO2-TPD, XPS, and H2-TPR, and the results indicated that flower CeO2 performed the largest acid-base sites and oxygen vacancies as expected, proving its superior physicochemical properties and catalytic activity. Moreover, the catalytic activity synthesis of DMC from CO2 and methanol was investigated, confirming that the flower CeO2 owned the highest catalytic performance, and the maximum yield of DMC was 3.11 mmol/gcat. under the reaction conditions (16 MPa, 250 °C, reaction time of 1 h without stirring). Importantly, the synthesis kinetic mechanism of DMC in dual supercritical systems was experimentally studied using the synthetic CeO2 catalysts, and the flower CeO2 catalyst possessed the lowest apparent activation energy of 45.9 kJ/mol, meanwhile, the initial reaction rate equation obtained from the experiment can be represented as: Rate = k [*] [CH3OH] [CO2]1/2, which was consistent with the reaction mechanism of Langmuir–Hinshelwood type. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Dual supercritical conditions CO2 conversion Dimethyl carbonate Kinetic mechanism CeO2 morphology Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Climate change has become a global issue due to the increasing amount of carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions into the atmosphere. Being the main component of greenhouse gas, CO2 is a non-toxic, abundant, inexpensive C1 renewable resource. Hence, the government attaches great attention to the reduction and utilization of CO2, and a lot of scientific researchers focus on the conversion of CO2 into high added-value chemicals. Unfortunately, CO2 is a very stable compound because of its highly oxidized state and thermodynamical stability, and the conversion and utilization of CO2 generally demand large energy input, that is, highly active reactants and catalysts are required to provide the necessary energy or depress the activation energy barrier [1,2]. For the typical CO2 transformation and utilization, the reductive transformation products may be methanol, formates, methane, while the organic carbonates, carbamates, ureas, carboxylates, polyurethanes, and polycarbonates could be gained through the non-reductive transformation. Since the non-reductive transformation need less energy than that of the reductive conversion, the conversion of CO2 to organic carbonate tends to be one of the economically non-reductive transformations, is desirable and promising [1], [3]. As the simplest and most industrially important organic carbonate, dimethyl carbonate (DMC) has been widely used in agrochemical and pharmaceutical industries because of its low toxicity and bioaccumulation, excellent biodegradability and solubility [4,5]. The DMC molecule contains several organic functional groups including methoxy, carbonyl and methyl groups, which could be used as a potential building block in the methylation [6–8] and carbonylation [9,10] reactions for replacing toxic precursors such as dimethyl sulfate (DMS) and phosgene [11]. Moreover, DMC may serve as a fuel additive to reduce CO, SOx and NOx emissions due to its high octane number (105) and oxygen content (53%) [12,13], and as an electrolyte in lithium-ion batteries for its low viscosity and eminent solubility [14,15]. DMC can be synthesized by various methods such as phosgenation, methanol oxidative carbonylation with CO, transesterification of propylene carbonate/ethylene carbonate with methanol, urea methanolysis and direct synthesis from CO2 and methanol [16–23]. Notably, the direct synthesis of DMC from CO2 and methanol was the most preferred route as it adheres to green chemistry principles [24]. This may actualize both the high-value utilization and chemical fixation of CO2, thereby alleviating the greenhouse effect. If DMC is produced via the direct synthesis route, some thermodynamics and kinetics constrain the synthesis process and industrial application of DMC [3,25]. In order to surmount these obstacles during the DMC synthesis, various highly active catalysts were prepared to promote the reaction system, and both the homogeneous and non-homogeneous catalysts were used for this reaction, such as K2CO3, KOH, n-Bu2Sn(OMe)2, ionic liquid, ZrO2, cerium-zirconium solid solution, CeO2-CaO, Y2O3, FexY1−xOy, Cu/CeO2, Co1.5PW12O40, and many other catalysts [12,16,17,20,26–39]. Meanwhile, CeO2 possesses a high density of Lewis acid-base sites and a corrugated surface atomic structure, which might enhance the reaction rate of CO2 and monohydric alcohols to organic carbonates by providing selectively catalytic sites to activate CO2 and forming energetically favorable carbonate intermediate [40]. Moreover, CeO2 has been synthesized with different morphologies including nanorod, nanocube, and nanooctahedron for use as catalyst or support. Based on the amount of acid-base active sites and oxygen vacancies, the activity order of C-O oxidation reactions on the CeO2 nanocrystal surface should obey nanorod > nanocube > nanooctahedron, and the CeO2 nanorods exhibited the highest reaction activity among all the prepared samples [13,41]. Currently, the direct synthesis DMC from CO2 and methanol under traditional conditions is generally hindered by the unfavorable solubility of CO2 in methanol, resulting in insufficient contact and activation between CO2 and the prepared catalyst. It is reported that the CO2 solubility in methanol tends to grow with increasing reaction pressure [42,43], and the CO2 solubility in methanol could obtain larger increasement when the reaction pressure exceeds its critical pressure, which can be easily calculated from the experimental data in Ref. [42]. Therefore, we proposed a dual supercritical condition for the direct DMC synthesis from CO2 and methanol. Meanwhile, the actual reaction partial pressures of CO2 and methanol surpass their critical pressures (7.1 MPa and 8.1 MPa). Since the supercritical fluids have strong solubility and excellent diffusion property, the dual supercritical conditions will undoubtedly increase the CO2 solubility in methanol, which can potentially facilitate the contact between CO2 and methanol and thus improve the reaction efficiency as expected. In our previous study [16], a dual supercritical conditions strategy was proposed to facilitate the synthesis of dimethyl carbonate (DMC) from CO2 and methanol, and the dual supercritical conditions were defined as: the synthesis temperature was higher than the critical temperatures of each reactant (>239 ℃), and the partial pressure for each reactant constituent was larger than its partial critical pressure (PCO2 > 7.4 MPa and Pmethanol > 8.1 MPa), respectively. However, direct synthesis DMC using CeO2 catalysts under dual supercritical conditions has not been reported. Moreover, the nanostructures of the CeO2 catalysts may become less stable and tend to sinter or dissolve under the high operation temperature restricted by the stringent dual supercritical states (>239 ℃). And the micro/nanostructured CeO2 was found to enhance the stability, reusability and may simplify the processing procedures without losing its instinct merits derived from basic units [44], this will prompt us to conduct this study. In this study, the CeO2 catalysts with different morphologies were designed and prepared for directly synthesizing DMC under the dual supercritical conditions. We using hydrothermal synthesis methods to prepare CeO2 catalysts with flower morphology, and also compared with amorphous and nanorod CeO2 catalysts for the experiment. The effects of catalyst surface acidity and the number of oxygen vacancies on the reaction performance of DMC synthesis from CO2 and methanol in the dual supercritical system were investigated through the experimental characterizations. In addition, the kinetic model of the direct synthesis DMC under dual supercritical conditions can provide some theoretical basis, so we have derived and discussed the kinetic model based on the Langmuir-Hinshelwood and used it to investigate the reaction mechanism of the direct DMC synthesis. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation Different methods were used to for the prepare CeO2 catalysts with different morphologies, meanwhile the amorphous CeO2 catalyst was directly calcined from cerium nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd, AR) at 550 °C for 4 h in air, and Ceria-flower (CeO2-F) and Ceria-nanorod (CeO2-R) were synthesized by the hydrothermal methods. Firstly, Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O of 2.604 g was filled in a beaker, added with 60 mL ethylene glycol (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd, AR) and 10 mL deionized water and stirred at room temperature for 30 min. Next the mixture was transferred to a 100 mL Teflon bottle for 1 h ultrasonic processing, and put into a stainless steel autoclave and sealed. Then the autoclave was placed in an electric blast drying oven at 180 ℃ for 24 h. After cooled and vacuum filtered, the sample was washed with deionized water and ethanol three times, and placed in an electric blast drying oven at 100 ℃ for 12 h. Eventually, the dried powder was calcined in a muffle furnace at 500 °C for 3 h to obtain the expected CeO2-F catalyst. For the preparation of CeO2-R, first dissolved 6.4 g NaOH and 3.0 g Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O in 40 mL and 30 mL deionized water, respectively. After stirring separately for 10 min, the two solutions were mixed slowly to gain a purple slurry. Next the slurry was stirred at room temperature for 30 min, after 1 h ultrasonic processing, and then transferred to a 100 mL Teflon bottle. Similarly sealed in an autoclave and placed in an electric blast drying oven at 100 °C for 24 h. After cooling, the powder was filtered under vacuum and washed three times with deionized water and ethanol, and dried in an electric blast drying oven at 100 ℃ for 12 h, and then calcined at 600 ℃ for 5 h to get the CeO2-R sample. The synthesis conditions of the catalysts with different morphologies were listed in Table 1. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations The powder X-ray diffraction patterns for the prepared catalysts were analyzed by a X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku Smart LAB SE, Japan) with Cu Kα radiation. Meanwhile the 2θ range was 15°− 85°, and the scan speed and step size were set as 5°/min and 0.02°, respectively. The crystalline grain size of the samples was calculated and estimated by the Scherrer equation. The particle size and appearance for different CeO2 catalysts were observed by scanning electron microscope (SEM) (Zeiss Sigma 300, Germany) at an accelerating voltage of 5.00 kV. The morphology micrographs of the CeO2 samples were taken by transmission electron microscope (TEM) (FEI Tecnai G2 F20) by using an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The N2 adsorption-desorption experiment was conducted on ASAP 2460 (Quantachrome Instrument, USA). Before the test, the samples were pretreated at 200 ℃ for 8 h under vacuum to remove the surface contaminants. Using the standard Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Brunauer-Joyner-Hallenda (BJH) methods, the specific surface area and pore size ( Table 2) of the catalysts were acquired at − 196 ℃, and the pore size distribution was shown in Fig. S1 in the Supporting information. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was detected on a Thermo ESCALAB 250Xi (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) spectrometer under a vacuum atmosphere with monochromatic Al Kα (1486.8 eV) as the source, and the XPS curves at 100 eV and 30 eV were recorded for the full spectrum and elemental high-resolution spectrum, respectively. The C1s line (284.8 eV) was taken as a reference to correct for electrostatic charging. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was measured with Quantachrome CBT-1 (Quantachrome Instrument, USA) to investigate the redox property of CeO2 samples, and the thermal conductivity detector (TCD) in this instrument was exploited to monitor the H2 consumption. Typically, about 50 mg of sample was placed into the U-shaped quartz tube and pretreated at 400 ℃ under He atmosphere, after maintaining this temperature for 30 min, the U-shaped quartz tube was cooled down to 50 ℃. Afterwards the H2 was introduced for 30 min, and then the sample was heated from 50 ℃ to 900 ℃ with a ramp rate of 10 ℃/min. Temperature-programmed desorption of NH3(NH3-TPD) was conducted on the MicrotracBEL-BELCAT II (MicrotracBEL, Japan) to determine the acidity amounts of the CeO2 catalysts. Meanwhile the 50 mg sample was heated to 500 °C for 30 min in He atmosphere and then cooled to 50 °C. Next the sample was adsorbed by 7.5% NH3/He for 60 min and then purged with He for 30 min. Finally, the sample was desorbed by heating up to 950 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Temperature programmed desorption of CO2 (CO2-TPD) was carried out on the MicrotracBEL-BELCAT II (MicrotracBEL, Japan) to detect the basic amounts of the CeO2 catalysts. The operation procedure was the same with NH3-TPD. 2.3 Catalyst evaluation All reactions for the direct synthesis DMC were carried out in a 100 mL autoclave equipped with an electromagnetic stirrer and thermocouple, and the temperature and stirring speed were regulated by a controller. Firstly, added 1 g prepared catalyst and 30 mL methanol (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd, AR) into the autoclave (In our tests, about 30 mL (743 mmol) methanol added in the 100 mL autoclave could get the supercritical condition), then sealed the reactor and replaced the air with CO2 three times. After heating the system to the desired temperature, CO2 was gradually introduced into the reactor to increase the desired pressure. When the temperature and pressure in the autoclave were stable, the heater was turned off after the reaction proceeded for a period of time. Next the autoclave was cooled to room temperature and fully decompressed after the direct synthesis reaction completed, and the liquid phase product was quantified by adding 1 g 1-Butanol (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd, AR) as an internal standard and stirred thoroughly. A capillary column KB-1701 (30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.50 µm) was employed to separate the liquid phase samples, and a Gas chromatograph with a flame ionization detector could actualize the analysis for methanol and DMC. The related experimental procedure was depicted in Fig. 1. The equation for DMC synthesis from CO2 and methanol as reactants was described as follows: (1) 2 CH 3 OH + CO 2 ⇌ CH 3 O 2 CO + H 2 O Meanwhile, the DMC yield was calculated using the following equation: (2) DMC yield mmol g ∙ catalyst = DMC produced mmol Catalyst g By using GC-MS for the sample analysis, the results manifested that only small impurity peaks could be observed, and the total peak area of these impurities is less than 3% that of the DMC (see the added carbon balance data in Supporting information Table S1). The methanol conversion could be expressed based on the equation below: (3) Methanol conversion % = 2 × DMC produced ( mmol ) Initial methanol ( mmol ) × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst morphologies analysis The CeO2 catalysts with different morphologies were observed by SEM and TEM, and the images were shown in Fig. 2. In Fig. 2(a) - (b), the CeO2 sample calcined from cerium nitrate (Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O) displayed a blocky structure with irregular shape surface, CeO2 (HRTEM image in Fig. 2(c) was (111) planes with an interplanar spacing of 0.31 nm calculated from the FFT pattern (Fig. 2(c)), and the selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern showed concentric circles. Fig. 2(d) - (e) disclosed the synthesized CeO2 nanorods with clustered structure. Even when the prepared nanorods gathered together, the resulting agglomerate still remained porous instead of close packed (Fig. 2(d)) [45], leading to the increased specific surface area of CeO2-R. The HRTEM image (Fig. 2(f)) revealed that the nanorod exposed a large amount of (110) planes with an interplanar spacing of 0.19 nm, and the selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern showed concentric circles, this means that it was polycrystalline. It was evident from Fig. 2(g) that the sectional view of the prepared CeO2-F (flower) exhibited as a layered accumulation, and the top view of CeO2-F appeared a distinct defection in the central area, indicating that the formation process of flower morphology could be explained as a triangular flake assembly [46]. TEM analysis was carried out to obtain the microstructure of a few selected samples. Fig. 2(h) presents the TEM image of the spheres, which shows a much darker and brighter contrast in the periphery and central part, respectively, confirming their hollow characteristics. CeO2-F HRTEM image in Fig. 2(i) was (110) planes with an interplanar spacing of 0.19 nm calculated from the FFT pattern. The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern showed spots, different of the concentric circles obtained from CeO2, indicating the presence of single crystal CeO2. Since inorganic single crystals have highly reactive surfaces [47] and regular and periodic arrangement of the inner particles. CeO2-F may expose more (110) planes. And the literature also shows that [20] the CeO2 (110) planes exhibits the lowest energy of formation of oxygen vacancy (+43.8 kcal·mol−1). This may result in higher concentration of oxygen vacancies and allow CeO2-F to have superior catalytic properties. 3.2 XRD analysis of prepared catalyst The XRD patterns of all synthesized catalysts were shown in Fig. 3. It can be seen from the figure that the characteristic peaks for CeO2 appeared at 28.6°、33.1°、47.6°、56.6°、59.2°、69.6°、76.8°, and 79.3°, which could be ascribed to (111), (200), (220), (311), (222), (400), (331), and (420) planes, respectively. This might be attributed to the cubic fluorite structure (unit cell parameter: a = 0.540 nm, space group of Fm−3m of CeO2. As a result, CeO2-F presented the weakest and broadest peak among all the prepared catalysts, signifying the existence of the smallest average crystallite size (7.6 nm), while the directly calcined CeO2 exhibited the sharpest peak with the highest intensity, indicating its largest average crystallite size accordingly. Table 2 summarized the average crystallite sizes (determined from the full width at half maximum) and crystallinity (determined from the peak intensity) of the prepared CeO2 with various morphologies [41], whose order was CeO2 >CeO2-R>CeO2-F, and the average crystallite sizes for CeO2-F and CeO2-R were close to those reported in the literature [46,48]. And CeO2-F has the largest specific surface area, surface area is related to crystal size of oxide, the smaller the crystal size, the higher surface area [1], this is also proved by the XRD calculation results. 3.3 Acid-base site detection by NH3/CO2-TPD It was reported that the weak and moderate basic-acidic sites of the catalysts as the key factors affecting the yield of DMC [49–51]. To further explore the acid-base properties of the surface, the NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD were employed to investigate the acidity and basicity of the prepared CeO2 samples with different morphologies, and the results were shown in Fig. 4. From Fig. 4(a) we can find that the desorption peaks of NH3-TPD at 50 – 200 ℃, 200 – 400 ℃ and > 400 ℃ belonged to the weak, medium and strong acidic sites, respectively, which were consistent with the desorption peaks of CO2-TPD. From the amount of NH3 desorbed at these acidic sites listed in Table 3, the weakly acidic behavior sites exhibited relatively large concentration in all three morphologies of CeO2, and the acidic sites were CeO2-F>CeO2-R>CeO2 in order, whose NH3 adsorption intensity (weak, medium, and strong) was in accordance with the trends of total acidity contents. The basic sites played a crucial role in the CO2 conversion and DMC formation [51,52], and the CO2-TPD characterization results were shown in Fig. 4(b) and Table 4. It could be revealed that CeO2-F possessed the largest number of weak and medium basic sites that followed the order of CeO2-F>CeO2-R>CeO2. Notably, the weak and medium basic sites were responsible for the activation of CO2 and contributed to the formation of methoxy groups in the DMC synthesis process, whereas the desorption for the product was difficult from the strong basic sites of the catalyst, and thus the DMC preparation may possibly occur at the weak and moderate basic sites [53]. Based on Lewis acid-base catalytic mechanism for the DMC synthesis, methanol and CO2 were activated by adsorption on Lewis acid-base sites, forming the active intermediates and then interact with each other to produce DMC and H2O [54]. During the reaction, the H atoms in the methanol can combine with the lattice oxygen on the catalyst surface, eventually the methanol dissociated into the adsorbed states -OCH3 and -H [55], while the CO2 adsorbed on the catalyst surface may be accomplished by the combined action of Lewis acidic and basic sites. Moreover, the unsaturated lattice oxygen on the coordination surface might provide electrons to the C-atoms in CO2 as Lewis basic sites, and CO2 could be adsorbed on the acid-base sites in a bidentate adsorption state. Meanwhile the C-O bond distance of CO2 in this adsorption state increases and the O-C-O bond angle decreases, this activates the CO2 molecule [56]. Therefore, the content of surface acid-base sites for the catalyst manifested its great influence on the DMC yield, and the CeO2-F catalyst was proved to own eminent acid-base active sites by characterization results, which may to the benefit of its prominent catalytic activity under the dual supercritical conditions. 3.4 Confirmation of oxygen species by XPS and H2-TPR analysis The surface oxygen species for CeO2 catalysts with different morphologies were detected and investigate by XPS, and the XPS spectra of Ce 3d and O 1 s were shown in Fig. 5. Fig. 5(a) depicted the Ce 3d spectra of the prepared catalysts, which can be fitted to eight peaks: V(∼882.2 eV), V′(∼884.2 eV), V″(∼888.5 eV), V‴(∼898.1 eV), U(∼900.6 eV), U′(∼902.4 eV), U″(∼907.2 eV), U‴ (∼916.4 eV), meanwhile the 4 U and 4 V bands represent the Ce 3d3/2 and Ce 3d5/2, respectively. Importantly, the 3d104f0 state of Ce4+ species were labeled as U‴, U″, U, V‴, V″ and V, whereas the 3d104f1 state of Ce3+ species were represented as U′ and V′ [13,57]. In addition, the V′ and U′ peaks can be used to quantitatively estimate the concentration ratio of Ce3+ to total Ce ions by calculating the area ratio between the V′, U′ peaks and the overall area of eight peaks based on the following equation: (4) C Ce 3 + % = A Ce 3 + A Ce 3 + + A Ce 4 + × 100 % where A Ce 3 + = A V ' + A U ' ; A Ce 4 + = A V + A V '' + A V ''' + A U + A U '' + A U ''' . A Ce 3 + : Peaks areas of Ce3+. A Ce 4 + : Peaks areas of Ce4+. In Table 5, the Ce3+ concentrations for the CeO2, CeO2-R and CeO2-F catalysts were 5.58% ± 0.21, 17.03% ± 0.15% and 17.99% ± 0.32, respectively. The presence of Ce3+ could generate oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface, and the oxygen vacancy concentration would grow as Ce3+ concentration increases [13], which was also testified by the XPS analysis results in Table 5. Moreover, the formation of oxygen vacancies may produce two unpaired electrons, encouraging the transformation from Ce4+ to Ce3+. Among the prepared CeO2 catalysts with different morphologies, the CeO2-F sample had the largest Ce3+ content and thus possessed the highest concentration of oxygen vacancies. Significantly, some scholars reported that oxygen vacancies were beneficial to the chemisorption of oxygen [58], thus the CeO2 rich in Ce3+ may have better absorption capacity for oxygen-containing species. And the oxygen vacancies on the CeO2 surface can enhance the conversion and activation of CO2 according to DFT calculation results [59,60]. Fig. 5(b) depicted the O 1 s spectra of the synthesized catalysts, exhibiting three oxygen species on the catalyst surface. The binding energy peaks at ∼529.2 eV and 530.2 eV were attributed to the surface lattice oxygen (OL) and O component associated with the O2− in surface oxygen vacancies (OV), respectively. The binding energy peaks at ∼531.5 eV could be ascribed to the surface chemisorbed oxygen (OC) including OH-, CO3 2- and O2-, etc [61,62]. Meanwhile, the oxygen vacancy concentration can be calculated by the peak area integration using the following Eq. (5), and the content of each oxygen species in the catalysts after the split-peak fitting calculation was tabulated in Table 5. (5) C O V % = A O V A O V + A O L + A O C × 100 % Where A O L , A O V and A O C represent the peak areas of lattice oxygen, surface oxygen vacancies and chemisorbed oxygen. From the table we can see that the oxygen vacancy concentrations in the prepared catalysts including CeO2, CeO2-R and CeO2-F were 3.22% ± 0.31, 13.56% ± 0.24% and 16.62% ± 0.38, respectively, which was coincident with the XPS results of Ce3+ content, further revealing that the reduction process of Ce4+ to Ce3+ might facilitate the unpaired electrons to create surface oxygen vacancies [63,64]. Moreover, the oxygen storage capacity (OSC) of the CeO2 with different morphologies was studied and analyzed by H2-TPR, and the results were shown in Fig. 6. Since CeO2 is a typical rare earth material and the element Ce has unfilled 4 f orbitals, under oxidation or reduction process, there is a rapid transition between Ce3+ and Ce4+ to form oxygen vacancies, and with the free electrons gather in the oxygen vacancies will promote the adsorption and activation of molecular oxygen, and finally improve the oxygen storage and release capacity of the catalyst. From Fig. 6 we observed that two obvious reduction peaks appeared at 300 ℃− 600 ℃, which can be divided into α and β peaks according to the literature [65]. Meanwhile the α and β peaks were considered to be caused by the oxygen vacancies and lattice oxygen reductions on the CeO2 surface, respectively. According to the quantitative analysis results tabulated in Table 5, the oxygen vacancy contents on the surfaces of CeO2, CeO2-R and CeO2-F were 0.07 ± 0.002 mmol/g, 0.11 ± 0.003 mmol/g and 0.14 ± 0.002 mmol/g, and the lattice oxygen concentrations were 0.42 ± 0.003 mmol/g, 0.44 ± 0.002 mmol/g and 0.52 ± 0.004 mmol/g, respectively, which was in reasonable agreement with the results of XPS analysis. Therefore, CeO2-F owned the higher OSC and reduction ability with the largest peak area (α + β) due to the decreased crystallite size [65]. The characterization results reveal that the three prepared catalysts are pure CeO2 phases without any impure atom dopant. Additionally, SAED results illustrate that only CeO2-F has single crystals diffraction spots, while the rest catalysts are polycrystalline. The FFT patterns reveal that both CeO2-F and CeO2-R expose (110) planes, but CeO2 is (111) planes. Many literatures convince that the CeO2 (110) surface exhibits the lowest formation energy of oxygen vacancy (+43.8 kcal·mol−1) [20], which may facilitate more oxygen vacancies generation. Moreover, the oxygen species were measured by XPS, and the results confirm that the oxygen vacancy concentrations obey the order: CeO2-F>CeO2-R>CeO2. Moreover, the oxygen species were measured by XPS, and the results confirm that the oxygen vacancy concentrations obey the order: CeO2-F>CeO2-R>CeO2. Since inorganic single crystals have highly reactive surfaces [47] and regular and periodic arrangement of the inner particles. CeO2-F may expose more (110) planes, resulting in higher concentration of oxygen vacancies. Furthermore, the N2-TPD and NH3/CO2-TPD results confirmed the same trend (CeO2-F>CeO2-R>CeO2) in terms of specific surface area and acid-base site concentration, respectively. 3.5 Catalytic activity evaluation Due to the unique characteristics in the supercritical fluids, several dual supercritical conditions were attempted to be employed in extraction and transesterification reactions [66,67]. Nevertheless, few scholars reported the supercritical methanol condition that participated in the DMC synthesis. According to our previous studies [16], the DMC synthesis yield using dual supercritical conditions could be significantly improved compared to that of the supercritical CO2 conditions, and thus we still use the dual supercritical conditions (T > 239 ℃, PCO2 > 7.4 MPa and Pmethanol > 8.1 MPa) to evaluate the catalytic performance of the prepared CeO2 samples. As a result, the catalytic performances of CeO2 with different morphologies were measured based on DMC yield, and the experimental results were illustrated in Fig. 7. In Fig. 7(a), the DMC yield grew as the reaction time extended at initial stage (within 1 h) under the setting reaction temperature and pressure, while the DMC yield dropped sharply after the reaction time exceeding 1 h, and the highest DMC yield for CeO2-F could achieve 3.11 mmol/gcat. at 250 °C. The reason for the rapid decrease of DMC yield after 1 h may be attributed to its hydrolytic at high temperatures [68]. By analyzing the samples after 1 h, the amount of methanol increased when the reaction exceeded 1 h, which further confirmed the assumptions. In Fig. 7(b), the catalytic performance of the prepared CeO2-F under supercritical CO2 conditions was also estimated, revealing the highest DMC yield was 1.48 mmol/gcat. at 110 °C for 6 h. Moreover, a few catalytic performance assessments on CeO2 with different morphologies were experimentally investigated, and the results were depicted in Fig. 8(a). It can be found from the figure that both CeO2-F and CeO2-R displayed good catalytic activity under the supercritical CO2 phase, whose maximal yield of DMC (both CeO2-F and CeO2-R) may reach 1.48 mmol/gcat., and the DMC yield for the amorphous CeO2 was only 1.05 mmol/gcat. Under dual supercritical conditions at 250 °C for 1 h, CeO2-F exhibited the top catalytic activity as expected, and the DMC yield and methanol conversion can achieve 3.11 mmol/gcat. and 0.84% respectively, which were 2.11 and 1.75 times than those under single supercritical CO2, verifying the eminent promotion of dual supercritical conditions in catalytic performance accordingly. For the prepared CeO2-R in Fig. 8(a), the DMC yield was 2.88 mmol/gcat. in dual supercritical fluids, indicating CeO2-F outperformed CeO2-R in the reaction, and the detailed experimental data were available in Fig. S2-S3 (Supporting information). Unfortunately for the amorphous CeO2 catalyst, its DMC yield and methanol conversion were respectively 2.27 mmol/gcat. and 0.61% under dual supercritical conditions, and the DMC yield in single supercritical CO2 could only reach 1.05 mmol/gcat., gaining approximate 1/3 yield and methanol conversion of CeO2-F under dual supercritical conditions (3.11 mmol/gcat. and 0.84%). Therefore, the CeO2-F catalyst can significantly improve both DMC yield and methanol conversion compared with the amorphous CeO2, proving its predominant catalytic performances, which was also in reasonable agreement with the characterization results of the prepared catalysts. This might be because CeO2-F owned the largest oxygen vacancy concentration (Table 5) and acid-base active sites (Tables 3 and 4), which tended to stimulate the adsorption activation of methanol and CO2. Since CO2 and methanol in the supercritical conditions had excellent solubility and diffusivity, the number of hydrogen bonding in methanol might decline under the supercritical state, which could isolate methanol as the individual molecule to react with CO2 and more easily adsorb on the catalyst surface [69], resulting in a more favorable interaction with each other. In addition, we also compared with some literatures and the results such as Table S2, we can see that relatively long reaction times were required to obtain high DMC yields, regardless of the CeO2 catalyst or other types of catalyst, and the maximum yield of DMC was 2.92 mmol/gcat. (T = 120 °C, P = 15 MPa, T = 24 h), which is a high yield obtained under prolonged high pressure conditions, but we achieved DMC yield was 3.11 mmol/gcat. in only 1 h under dual supercritical conditions. If the industrialization process to maintain high temperature and pressure conditions for a long time required more stringent experimental equipment, which was a serious disadvantage for industrialization. According to our theoretical and experimental studies, not only the reaction time is significantly reduced, the higher DMC yield can be achieved in only 1 h under dual supercritical conditions, it also does not require stir equipment. This may solve the problem of batch production in the future and bring more possibilities to industrialization. Under the same conditions (P = 16 MPa, T = 250 °C, reaction time 1 h), the repeated use experiments of three consecutive cycles for the as-prepared CeO2 samples were performed to estimate the stability of the catalysts. After each run, the catalyst was separated from the product, and reused for the next cycle when the desiccation and calcination processes were completed. In Fig. 8(b), the cycle test results showed that the catalytic activities for CeO2-F, CeO2-R and CeO2 decreased 4.8%, 8.7% and 13.9% respectively, signifying that CeO2-F catalyst behaved an outstanding recycle stability with less than 5% performance degradation. Moreover, the XRD pattern of the as-prepared CeO2 after the cycling test (Fig. S4) can disclose the reason. Meanwhile, both the spent CeO2-R and CeO2 exhibited sharp peaks with relatively high intensities, indicating their average crystallite sizes increased compared to the fresh catalysts. As shown in Fig. S5, the SEM images of CeO2-F presented an insignificantly morphology change before and after DMC reaction, whereas the overall morphology of CeO2-R became more compacted and gathered much tighter, which may be due to the high operation temperature restricted by the stringent dual supercritical states. In brief, these recycle use results convinced the relatively stable catalytic activity for the CeO2-F catalyst as desired. In addition, the amounts of reactants and products are carefully measured to ensure the material balance. 3.6 Dual supercritical conditions comprehensive performance evaluation Direct synthesis of DMC from CO2 and methanol using dual supercritical conditions has shown satisfactory results, while to compare and analyze the real benefit of dual supercritical conditions, a lot of factors need to be included, such as reaction time, temperature, pressure, DMC yield, conversion of methanol and equipment investment, etc. A multi-element valued model [70] was applied to achieve the performance comparison and assessment of 4 different reaction conditions. The results of the superiority calculations show that the dual supercritical conditions have relatively advantageous and worth considering, and provide an important theoretical basis for future research. 4 Reaction mechanism and kinetic analysis 4.1 The proposed catalytic mechanism for synthesis DMC Based on our previous study [72–74], the catalytic mechanism of direct synthesis DMC from CO2 and methanol under dual supercritical states was proposed after deep analysis and discussion. As shown in Fig. 9, the catalytic reaction for DMC synthesis proceeded as follows: firstly, an O atom from CO2 may enter an oxygen vacancy in the CeO2 and was adsorbed on the catalyst surface, then a bridging carbonate or bidentate carbonate structure was formed after the C atom in the CO2 interacting with the lattice oxygen on the catalyst surface [13]. During the next procedure, Lewis acid site on the catalyst surface would adsorb the O atom in the methanol, while the H atom from the methanol could also combine with the lattice oxygen on the catalyst surface, afterwards the methanol dissociates into the adsorbed active intermediate, completing the activation of the reactant molecule [55]. Next, the obtained active intermediates of CO2 and methanol further react to form the methyl carbonate, which subsequently combines with the activated methanol to produce the desirable DMC, and the former O atom inserted into the oxygen vacancy becomes the lattice oxygen on the CeO2 surface, replacing the original oxygen vacancy that lost before. Finally, the H+ atom dissociated from methanol interacts with the lattice oxygen on the CeO2 surface to produce H2O molecule, generating another oxygen vacancy simultaneously [75,76]. The H2-TPR and XPS characterization results (Table 5) confirmed that the prepared CeO2 samples was rich in oxygen vacancies and lattice oxygen on the catalysts surface, and the concentrations of both oxygen vacancies and lattice oxygen could affect the formation of DMC [77,78]. Meanwhile, Ce3+ and Ce4+ in the CeO2 behaved the advantages of rapid and reversible transformation, thus facilitated the generation of a certain number of oxygen vacancies on its surface of metal oxides, which will promote the activation of CO2 [79,80] and was further verified by DFT calculation results in the literature [81], signifying that the C-O bond cleavage on oxygen vacancies required lower activation potential energy than that of on the metal cations. Consequently, the oxygen vacancies on the CeO2 surface were considered to serve as the active center for catalyzing direct synthesis DMC from CO2 and methanol, which further promoting the activation of CO2 and reaction rate. 4.2 Kinetic model establishment and analysis The kinetic mechanism with its models are generally used to describe and predict the actual reaction process of direct synthesis DMC from CO2 and methanol, whose theoretical elucidation and model parameters can be obtained and testified by the experimental data. According to our proposed synthesis mechanism of DMC, both activation and reaction processes of all substances occur on the catalyst surface, which may provide the essential place for the occurance of rate-controlling step during the reaction. This is consistent with the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (LH) and Eley-Rideal (ER) mechanisms proposed in the literatures [25,45,62,82]. Theoretically, the LH mechanism assumes that CO2 and methanol could be interacted with the prepared catalyst in the corresponding step 1 and 2 respectively, meanwhile the CO2 adsorption and activation rates may possibly determine the DMC yield [45]. While the ER mechanism ignores the CO2 activation process on the catalyst surface, supposing that CO2 reacts directly with the activated CH3OH adsorbed on the catalyst surface, and the CH3OH adsorption seems to be much stronger with the CH3OH* and CO2 combination as the rate-determining step [34]. Accordingly, we have reason to suspect that the ER mechanism is not sufficient to account for the kinetic process of catalytic synthesis DMC in the dual supercritical conditions, which is mainly due to ignoring the adsorption and activation of CO2 on the catalyst surface even if they are much weaker than those of methanol. For the model establishment and deduction in this study, we firstly hypothesized each reaction step as the rate-determining step, suggesting that other steps preceded very quickly, and the reaction rate of each deduced step can be expressed in terms of the concentrations of reactants and catalysts. After meticulous deduction and calculation procedures(in the Supporting information), we can acquire the rate equations under various rate-determining steps by using LH and ER mechanisms, and the results were tabulated in Table 6. Since few related kinetic investigation on the direct synthesis DMC from CO2 and methanol under dual supercritical conditions is reported, it is vital significance to investigate and determine the rate-controlling step and model parameters, which can precisely describe and predict the direct DMC synthesis process, expecting to improve the DMC yield and methanol conversion effectively, and providing data for future industrialization. 4.3 Determination of rate-controlling step and model parameters To explore the kinetic mechanism of direct synthesis DMC from CO2 and methanol under dual supercritical conditions, we experimentally studied and determined the rate equation and model parameters for the prepared CeO2-F, CeO2-R and CeO2 catalysts. Due to the discontinuous detection and varying reaction pressure inside the intermittent reactor, the kinetic experiments were conducted to measure the reaction rate based on the DMC yield within the prescribed time, using the ice water bath for instant cooling of the DMC samples inside the autoclave. According to the experimental results (Fig. S6 in the Supporting information), the reaction rate (dCDMC/dt) was calculated on the basis of the DMC yields at 30 min (reaction time) for different catalysts, and the apparent activation energies of CeO2 with different morphologies were obtained according to the fitting lines of Arrhenius equation ( Fig. 10(a)). Meanwhile, the apparent activation energies under dual supercritical conditions of CeO2-F, CeO2-R and CeO2 were 45.9 kJ/mol, 48.3 kJ/mol and 66.9 kJ/mol respectively, suggesting that the CeO2-F structure can boost the catalytic activity of ceria beyond its improvement in surface area. Although the reaction rate constant was essentially controlled by temperature, pressure and activation energy, the overall reaction rate was also affected by the reactant concentration and catalyst loading [45]. Generally, the kinetic equation for evaluating the DMC conversion could be expressed as: (10) Rate = k * a CH 3 OH b CO 2 c Where k is the rate constant for the overall reaction; [*] denotes the active site concentration for the prepared catalyst, calculated on the unit mass of the added catalyst; a, b and c represent the reaction order determined by experimental data. Due to the micron/nanostructural catalyst particles used in DMC synthesis, the internal diffusion can be neglected during the reaction process. Since the external diffusion was closely related to the turbulence degree of the reactants, the effect of stir speed on the DMC yield was studied and the results were listed in the Table S5. It can be concluded from the table that the DMC yield almost remained unchanged with various stir speed, even without stir, implying that the external diffusion effect was negligible under the dual supercritical conditions. Afterwards, a few experiments with different reactant concentrations and the amount of catalyst were carried out, and the corresponding kinetic curves were plotted in double logarithmic coordinates. As shown in Fig. 10(b-d), the slopes of the fitted lines can be employed to gain the reaction order values of a, b and c, and the detailed data were summarized in Table S6-S9 in the Supporting information. In Fig. 10(b), there was a positive correlation between the amount of catalyst (0.25–1 g) and the reaction rate, which might because the increasing addition of the catalyst may promote the active sites, leading to the concentration improvement of the activated reactants and the subsequent increase in reaction rate. Importantly, from the fitted lines in Fig. 10(b) we can witness that the catalyst reaction orders (a in Eq. (10)) for the CeO2-F, CeO2-R and CeO2 catalysts were 0.89, 0.92 and 0.76 respectively, presenting approximately + 1 order reaction for the three prepared catalysts. Moreover, when the amount of catalyst was over 1 g, no significant increase of the DMC yield could be observed, implying that the optimal the amount of CeO2 catalyst in this reaction was 1 g. For the methanol dosage in Fig. 10(c), we can see the similarly positive correlation tendency in the direct DMC synthesis under dual supercritical conditions, owing to the concentration increase of reactant (methanol) as usual. It was apparent from Fig. 10(c) that the methanol reaction orders (b in Eq. (10)) of CeO2-F, CeO2-R and CeO2 corresponded to 0.88, 0.92 and 1.15, also can be regarded as + 1 order in DMC reaction. Fig. 10(d) also displayed the logarithmic relationship between CO2 pressure and DMC synthesis rate, and the experimental results revealed that the CO2 pressure was positively correlated with the reaction rate. According to the slopes obtained from the fitted lines in the figure, CeO2-F, CeO2-R and CeO2 corresponded to the reaction orders (c in Eq. (10)) of 0.53, 0.57 and 0.62, which can be seen as the reaction order of + 1/2. In summary, the rate equations for the direct DMC synthesis from CO2 and methanol under dual supercritical conditions were formulated as: (11) Rate = k * 0.76 ∼ 0.92 CH 3 OH 0.88 ∼ 1.15 CO 2 0.53 ∼ 0.62 According to our proposed catalytic mechanism for DMC synthesis, CO2 could be activated in the oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface, while the adsorption and activation site of methanol may occur on the lattice oxygen of the catalyst, and thus the contents of oxygen vacancies and hydroxyl groups on the catalyst surface would directly affect the synthesis rate of DMC [62]. Moreover, the XPS and H2-TPR characterization results (Table 5) discovered that the lattice oxygen concentration was much larger than that of the oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface, signifying that methanol could be activated more sufficiently on the catalyst surface than that of CO2. This would limit the generation rate of direct DMC synthesis from CO2 and methanol under dual supercritical conditions, which might be the reason for the low CO2 reaction order (c=0.53–0.62) in the rate Eq. (11). Substantially, the crucial assumption in the LH kinetic model considered the CO2 and methanol adsorption and activation processes occur independently at different sites of the catalyst, further validating the rationality of our proposed DMC synthesis mechanism in dual supercritical conditions. As a result, the rate equation for the direct DMC synthesis under dual supercritical conditions can be expressed based on the fitted results of experimental data. As formulated in Eq. (12), this was in agreement with the derivated rate equation in LH model using step 4 (generation of DMC) as the rate-controlling step (Table 6), confirming our correct hypothesis that the ER mechanistic model is unsuitable for describing the direct synthesis DMC under dual supercritical conditions. (12) Rate = k * 1 CH 3 OH 1 CO 2 1 / 2 To further develop the prepared CeO2-F with excellent catalytic performance, we calculated and obtained the related model parameters based on the experimental data and fitting results, and the detail kinetic model can be expressed as follows: (13) Rate = k[*](0·89) [CH3OH](0·88) [CO2](0·53) Where k is 0.0013 (250 ℃) according to the calculation results. Therefore, the obtained kinetic model can precisely describe and predict the direct DMC synthesis process, expecting to improve the DMC yield and methanol conversion effectively. 5 Conclusion The experiment and kinetic mechanism were studied for the direct synthesis DMC from CO2 and methanol in dual supercritical conditions over different CeO2 catalysts, and the results showed that the prepared CeO2-F sample owned an outstanding catalytic activity, with the highest DMC yield of 3.11 mmol/gcat. at 250 °C and 16 MPa (dual supercritical conditions) in 1 h. Meanwhile, the activation energy for the prepared CeO2-F catalyst was calculated as 45.9 kJ/mol after the fitting line based on the experimental data, which was substantially lower than the previously reported CeO2 catalysts[25]. Moreover, the kinetic model and mechanism were built and analyzed, and the generation of DMC was determined as the rate-controlling step, which was consistent with the rate equation in the LH mechanism model. Eventually, the kinetic model for the prepared CeO2-F catalyst using in the direct synthesis DMC from CO2 and methanol under dual supercritical conditions was calculated and achieved by the experimental and fitting results, whose rate equation can be expressed as: Rate= 0.0013[*](0.89) [CH3OH](0.88) [CO2](0.53). This study may be beneficial to improve the DMC yield and methanol conversion, and is bound to have a promising application and development in the near future. coredata.dc:description: In this study, the direct synthesis conditions of dimethyl carbonate (DMC) from methanol and CO2 were controlled under the dual supercritical conditions, whose temperature was higher than the maximal critical temperature of CO2 and methanol (>239 ℃), and the partial pressure for each reactant was larger than its partial critical pressure (PCO2 > 7.4 MPa and Pmethanol > 8.1 MPa). A series of CeO2 catalysts with different morphologies including traditional nanorod, amorphous and flower structures were synthesized by hydrothermal method. The prepared catalysts were characterized by the BET, XRD, SEM, NH3/CO2-TPD, XPS, and H2-TPR, and the results indicated that flower CeO2 performed the largest acid-base sites and oxygen vacancies as expected, proving its superior physicochemical properties and catalytic activity. Moreover, the catalytic activity synthesis of DMC from CO2 and methanol was investigated, confirming that the flower CeO2 owned the highest catalytic performance, and the maximum yield of DMC was 3.11 mmol/gcat. under the reaction conditions (16 MPa, 250 °C, reaction time of 1 h without stirring). Importantly, the synthesis kinetic mechanism of DMC in dual supercritical systems was experimentally studied using the synthetic CeO2 catalysts, and the flower CeO2 catalyst possessed the lowest apparent activation energy of 45.9 kJ/mol, meanwhile, the initial reaction rate equation obtained from the experiment can be represented as: Rate = k [*] [CH3OH] [CO2]1/2, which was consistent with the reaction mechanism of Langmuir–Hinshelwood type.
coredata.dc:title: Performance and kinetic investigations on the CeO2 catalyzed direct synthesis of dimethyl carbonate from CO2 and methanol in dual supercritical conditions
